author: Tree Wallace
comment: Thanks for what u do!  Don‚Äôt know this cat as I‚Äôm further East - but it doesn‚Äôt look like he has a ‚Äòtipped ear‚Äô so not sure if he is fixed.  Being a male u can generally tell if u can get a good look from behind - can u tell if he has a full scrotum?  If so, I‚Äôd b happy to trap him to get him fixed (or can lend u a trap).  DDFL fixes all cats for free!  It will keep him from impregnating every female in the neighborhood PLUS it keeps him from getting in cat fights - very common amongst the males! I‚Äôve done TNR for years & it is the males that r in the worst shape - with pus pouring out of their ears, or full blown abscesses, cuts & scratches.  When they r not fixed they declare their territory & fight to protect it!  So let me know if u need him fixed! ‚ù§Ô∏è

author: Gina Cuomo
comment: Thanks Tree! He actually has a tipped ear, which is great. But thank you SO much for offering to help. :)

author: Tree Wallace
comment: Oh good, I couldn‚Äôt tell!  It is so hard on them in this cold weather - another thought is if he is a sweetie & u want to bring him in - is to trap him, carry him in & keep him contained in a room where he can‚Äôt hide from u - so like a bathroom & u start by feeding him soft/canned food from a spoon.  Then he associates u with food.  After awhile u may b able to pet him.  U can start by using the handle of a wooden spoon! Maybe stroke him as u feed him?  Then eventually he can have free rein in the house.  He may not ever b an ‚Äòaffectionate‚Äô cat but may be safer & warmer inside for the winter.  Then come spring u can let him come & go - so he has freedom but know u r his food source!  ???

author: Gina Cuomo
comment: He seems to be doing pretty alright with the shelter we built - it has an electric blanket. haha But its the times we don't see him for 3-4 days, like this past week. Its been so cold that I hope he's with someome else as crazy as us. Ha

author: Gail Schultz
comment: Thank you üíú

author: Jessica Guerin

author: Bev Laughlin
comment: My neighbor and I were feeding a stray for 3 yrs.  He would come the same time everyday to eat. Could never get close to him.  He stayed  in the parkway in the bushes when it was very cold.  We put dry food out in case we would miss him and wet food in the evening.  Then he disappeared.  As long as you keep food out he will keep coming back.  Thanks for taking care of him!!!

author: Doreen Rp
comment: Water is hard to find for animals in this city and so important.  My mom is in the country and a neighbors dog & cats come in all weather for a drink in cattle tank.

author: Bev Laughlin
comment: Also, birds and squirrels have a hard time getting water in the winter. Try to put water out for them. THANKS

author: Karen Kaiser
comment: We had the very same experience with a Siamese cat that we found in January outside getting warm on our greenhouse roof. We fed him for over five years and let him into our home and garage. He loved our cat, but would not let us too near him. One summer he disappeared for good. We gave him some good years and so did someone else when he‚Äôd leave for weeks at a time. I always hoped someone was able to take him in.

author: Carol Brown
comment: I have lived in Park Hill for many many years.  I have always had dogs & cats.  long ago I had cats that were indoor/outdoor, but I lost a couple that I loved, & more recently decided that I would no longer let my cats out at all.  I have a cat that a grandson gave me who had been a street cat (young).  I got him fixed, put him in the house with the others, & did not let him out. He tried for awile to get out, I stopped him or went out & caught him & brought him back in. He has adjusted & doesn't try any more.  my dogs spend time in the back yard which they cannot get out of,  I do sympathize with all of you who seem to have fairly frequent escapees, but you can control it.....

author: Jane Skarka
comment: Hi Gina,

author: Tree Wallace
comment: yes, awhile back i was trying to trap a neighbor's cat who escaped when paramedics arrived when she had a stoke.  i did trap a cat but it wasn't her's.  i knew he wasn't totally feral so he lived in my BR for a month.  i had taken him to my vet (montclair) and was told he didn't have a chip.  i tried my best to get him tamer but after a month i wan't making much progress. he was letting me pet him but not enjoying it.  & never would come to me.   i brought him to the cat care society so he'd not be caged.  within 2 hours he was with his original owners!!!! turns out he had a chip!!!  i informed my vet that their chip reader wasn't working or their technique????  anyway, the owner said he was a feral they were using as a 'barn' type cat gotten from DDFL as a barn cat.  it was never friendly. he lived outdoors. they 'lost' him a year ago.  so, after all that time 'away' and then a month with my almost constant attention, he ended up being their house cat!!!  that's why i recommended they give him a try indoors - cause as sweet as he is, there is hope! gina, is there any chance you'd bring him in, if jane or i help?

author: Arlyn LaBair
comment: I have a cat that was a barn cat for her first 6 months and decided a while back to go back to living on the street. I hope that someone is taking as good of care as you.  I have a chip checker if you do catch him.

author: Debra Taylor
comment: I had one of my ferals in North Park Hill get accidently locked in a garage for about 2 weeks.. poor thing was so skinny when we got the people aware.  This poor cat needs a companion.. is your shelter insulated, or just a box?

author: Aimee Lloyd
comment: Good for you Gina!  I have 2 ferals that I take care of and feed - they live in my garage and come into my home both morning and evenings for food but like to be outside.  I am happy that you are the kind, compassionate person that you are - taking care of this kitty!  Keep up the good work!!

author: Martha Pearse
comment: That grey cat looks exactly like the one I've been feeding since early January. Big Kitty! I feed on the front porch at sundown--the cat is quite punctual. And, have made a comfy space in the garage with heat and everything except a mint on the pillow. So far, only the food seems to be used. Now, after one previously failed attempt, I got him/her trapped last night and soon we are on our way to Feline Fix.  I hope to find a chip.  If not, well,I'll figure that out when I have to. Much as I'd love to have another cat, the resident two cats and two dogs seem to think otherwise.

author: Arlyn LaBair
comment: Is that the cat that you thought was pregnant?

author: Marty Johnson
comment: I have a gray feral male (Borris) and his aunt (Natasha) who have been in my care for over 10 years.  I have fed them both since she was a year old and Borris was born next to my garage.  They were both spayed and neutered a long time ago and now have a heated house on the porch.  I feed them twice a day and they get fresh water as well.  Yes, me and my husband are cat people and no regrets.  A long time ago there were a number of gray cats that were born in Park Hill and at that time we were taking care of four kittens and Natasha.  Natasha is a short haired gray and white and her sister, who is Borris' mother was a long haired gray.  Borris does have a sister who is also a long haired gray.  I believe Borris' mother is dead now and oddly enough his sister did show up on the porch about two years ago and both Borris and Natasha treated her as if she was family.  It was a nice little reunion but unfortunately that was the last time I saw her. The cat in this picture looks a lot like my cat Borris but it can't be him since he doesn't leave the area very much and since he's coming down with arthritis, I doubt it since he does limp.  We live on MLK Blvd & Clermont.

author: Tracey Trenam

author: Gina Cuomo

author: Martha Pearse
comment: Hmm. Thought I posted last night but don't see it. So, here's an update in case I messed up the posting.  Trapped the big grey cat (really a Russian Blue). Feline Fix was helpful but was backed up, so I took him (I think he's a him) to DDFL with  hopes that Azul (yes, I named him. Couldn't stop myself) is a little bit tame and they might be able to put him into their socialization program. The woman at Feline Fix spent quite a bit of time with us, and tried a few moves that make me believe he has at least rudimentary socialization. Can't believe I got so attached.  I was so happy that I trapped him the night before, and that he spent the night in his covered cage in a nice warm hallway...I couldn't sleep. I felt like I'd just given birth.

author: Arlyn LaBair
comment: Martha you worked REALLY had to rescue this guy... you are a real angel!

author: Martha Pearse
comment: Arlyn LaBair No one spent as much energy on finding a lost cat as you did.  I wish "Azul" had been the one. You are the one working hard!  Say...this boy seems to have real potential. Seems I have a talent for that (tho it's not always a good trait), and you might check DDFL after a bit to see if he's socialized and looking for a mom like you.  His ID is A0822584, surrendered 2/13/2020.

author: David Vogel
comment: I‚Äôm hesitant to respond in a forum that doesn‚Äôt lend itself to discussions about such a complex and emotional topic, but there‚Äôs also a big part of me that can‚Äôt let this go unanswered. John Stossel‚Äôs segment is far from a constructive examination of homelessness. His intent was really just to give people an excuse for demonizing homeless people by viewing them as lazy, dishonest, and undeserving of our help. There is so much readily available information out there that attempts to address this topic from a more constructive perspective, and I hope people will seek out that information rather than relying on shallow and histrionic segments like this. That‚Äôs all I‚Äôm going to say because I know this is going to get ugly fast, and I don‚Äôt want to be part of that.

author: Diane Mandile
comment: I agree, this is a complex situation. I do think it's worth sharing the varied sides of this story.(edited)

author: Valerie Sarni
comment: Agree, that poorly constructed "video" clearly already knew what look it wanted to portray when they filmed it. I hope people have the intelligence to not just swallow that garbage whole but rather understand that homelessness is a far more complex and multi layer issue than that video showed.(edited)

author: Caren Henderson
comment: This was created by a political consulting group. Just sayin.

author: Diane Mandile
comment: But, were the interviews faked? It's definitely a complex issue. But one that many people have a blindside about

author: Diane Mandile
comment: I sometimes lower the window and hand over donation. I'm sure I'll continue to do that. For me it's the ones who look like my own kids that tug at my heart. For others it could be someone who looks like a veteran or a single parent or whatever. I don't know their story but I'm compelled to connect. I also donate through non-profit channels.  I still think this video has some lessons to share.

author: Caren Henderson
comment: My point is that the group who made this has an agenda. With election season coming up, we all should be more wary of stuff like this. I say leave it on Facebook and let NextDoor be about neighbors helping neighbors. As for the interviews - real or fake, I don‚Äôt agree with sweeping generalizations of groups of people which is what this video is trying to make - beware of all homeless people.

author: Cindi Mathers

I can assure you that the homeless we serve are only getting necessary items to help them get back on track like clothing, and hygiene items, shoes, backpacks etc. We still DESPERATELY need ADULT COLD WEATHER clothes, jeans and the above items. You can drop off at 9291 E 59th N Pl

author: Margaux Milchen
comment: I always give cash donations directly to them. I enjoy doing it!! I gave a $10 bill to a panhandler yesterday at montview and Central Park and he picked up his backpack and walked off afterwards. Maybe that day he gets to eat or whatever he wants to do, I don't judge... and don't care what he does with it. üòÅ(edited)

author: Kerri Peek

author: Margaux Milchen
comment: Just give them cash.

author: Kerri Peek
comment: Margaux Milchen I am a Disabled Veteran, I never have cash. If I did I would. I do end up with free food vouchers. I'm not very mobile around town, due to being blind and with a cane. So if someone looks mobile, I am more than happy to share what little I have to share. When I have cash, I give it. I was a homeless Vet for 5 years. We were fortunate to be in a motel, but there were a few months when I couldn't afford the motel and was in the streets. No I don't drink or do drugs, I'm just a Disabled Vet.  I never panhandled though.  Thought about it, but I figured people would be cruel to me and I didn't need that on top of everything else. You can't tell I am blind if you look at me. You can tell that there was facial nerve damage, my face falls.

author: Georgia Cerros
comment: Honestly, social media is the new way to panhandle. All you have to do is tell a sad story. No standing outside with a sign needed. No need to stand in line to receive food or assistance with everyone else. There are no papers to fill out. Everything you want will be delivered to your door for free and more. If you are unhappy with what you receive you can always sale it for cash. Sites like Next Door will start to become the same as seeing the homeless on the streets. It‚Äôs just one step up. It‚Äôs just a different platform. It‚Äôs smart.

author: Gloria BURNS
comment: what i did was call 311 it took me about two years i was on my own. when you live next to renters they don't get involved. i did had to call the police a few times then they see i was not going to stop finally the land lord got the ones living in the camper to go then the mechanic shop right next to my house the city got them to move. i stress so much i lost 35 lb my Doctor was worried we are living in bad times so all i can say find out where all of us can get help to not be in fear.check out the library some times a police person will give you some good suggestion if we all work together we can have some kind of peace. we can do it but not alone like i had to but one suggestion you know what you have to do is to make it very very hard for them to enter your space. wishing you the best.

comment: Looking for a fun outing to select this year‚Äôs live Christmas tree and support two good causes in the process?  A Denver couple is offering Christmas trees on their Grand County ranch (north of Silverthorne) to anyone who makes a donation to The Delores Project -- which they will match! The Delores Project provides safe, reliable shelter and other services to women experiencing homelessness.
